message_1: What is the half-life of a radioactive isotope that decays by 50% after 10 years, and what fraction of the original radioactive material will remain after 30 years?
message_2:
The half-life of a radioactive isotope is the time it takes for half of the original material to decay. In this case, the isotope decays by 50% after 10 years, which means its half-life is 10 years.

To find the fraction of the original radioactive material remaining after 30 years, we can use the formula:

Remaining fraction = (1/2)^(t / T)

where t is the time elapsed (30 years) and T is the half-life (10 years).

Remaining fraction = (1/2)^(30 / 10)
Remaining fraction = (1/2)^3
Remaining fraction = 1/8

So, after 30 years, 1/8 of the original radioactive material will remain.
